simple.description: Size of correlation window in samples.
Input overlap in samples. Must be smaller then correlationSize. Negative numbers are allowed which means you skip input data between corelation windows
Block average output frames. How many averages on each output. Use numAverages<=1 for no output averaging.

NORMAL is the standard autocorrelation layout where the center spike is in the middle of the output frame and you have 2*correlationSize+1 points
ROTATED flips the front and back of the display. This puts the center spike at index 0 and frame index chorosponds exactly to the delay. This makes it easy to measure the correlation delay. There are still 2*correlationSize+1 points per output frame.
SUPERIMPOSED is like ROTATED but the 2nd half of the output frame is flipped and added to the first 1/2. This means the output frame consists of exactly correlationSize output samples. Autocorrelation will be approximatly symetric for indicies close to 0 since the correlation output for a dealay of N is approximatly the same as an advance of N for small N. The superposition adds the correlation output for the delay as well as the advace to get twice the averaging effect.
Remove mean prior to correlating. If there is a mean this causes a bias in the output frame shape since more samples are available for correlation for smaller delays then larger delays.
Zero out the output value chorosponding to no delay. This will always be a "huge" value. So zero it out so it doesn't overshaddow the rest of the outputs.
